Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.redis.codec

RESP (Redis Serialization Protocol) codec for Redis client communication.

This package provides encoding and decoding for the Redis protocol, supporting both RESP2 (Redis 2.0+) and RESP3 (Redis 6.0+) formats.

RESP Data Types

RESP defines several data types, each prefixed by a single byte:

RESP Data Types
PrefixTypeExample
+Simple String+OK\r\n
-Error-ERR unknown command\r\n
:Integer:1000\r\n
$Bulk String$6\r\nfoobar\r\n
*Array*2\r\n$3\r\nfoo\r\n$3\r\nbar\r\n

Null Values

Null bulk strings are represented as $-1\r\n. Null arrays are represented as *-1\r\n.

Key Components

  • RESPType - Enumeration of RESP data types
  • RESPValue - Represents a decoded RESP value
  • RESPDecoder - Decodes RESP wire format to values
  • RESPEncoder - Encodes commands to RESP wire format
  • RESPException - Protocol parsing errors

Usage Example


 // Encoding a command
 RESPEncoder encoder = new RESPEncoder();
 ByteBuffer command = encoder.encodeCommand("SET", "mykey", "myvalue");

 // Decoding a response
 RESPDecoder decoder = new RESPDecoder();
 decoder.receive(responseBuffer);
 RESPValue value = decoder.next();
 if (value != null) {
     if (value.isSimpleString()) {
         String reply = value.asString();  // "OK"
     }
 }

Streaming Decoding

The decoder handles partial data gracefully. If a complete RESP value cannot be parsed from the available data, next() returns null and the decoder retains the partial data for the next receive().

Thread Safety

Encoder instances are thread-safe. Decoder instances are not thread-safe and should be used from a single thread (typically the SelectorLoop thread).

Author:
Chris Burdess
